name: Berlin
intro_vibe: The Capital of Cool: Where history meets counterculture and the night never ends.

general_info.description: Berlin is not Germany—it is its own universe. A city of contrasts where bullet-scarred history meets hedonistic nightlife. From the freedom of Tempelhofer Feld to the grit of Neukölln, Berlin is raw, real, and unapologetically alternative. Time flows differently here; a 'weekend' can last 72 hours.

weather_breakdown.name: December
pros: New Year's Eve at Brandenburg Gate

etiquette_tips: Cash Anxiety is Real: 'Nur Bar' (Cash Only) is common even in trendy restaurants. Cards are randomly refused. ATMs run out of money on Saturday nights. Always carry €50 in cash.
Silence is Respect: Berliners value privacy. No small talk in elevators, quiet on the train, and no fake smiles. A neutral face is not hostility, it is respect for your space.
Rules are Sacred: You wait for the green light (Ampelmann), even at 3am on an empty street. Jaywalking is socially judged. Rules are the social contract that holds the chaos together.
Sunday Reality: Sunday is for 'Ruhe' (rest). Shops, supermarkets, and pharmacies are closed. No drilling, no loud music, no glass recycling. The city shuts down.
The Späti Culture: The 'Späti' (late-night corner store) is the center of social life. Grab a beer (€1.50) and sit on the bench outside. It is the Berlin way.
Club Protocol: No photos. Ever. Sticker your camera. Dress casually (black helps), know the DJ, and don't be drunk in line. The queue is serious business; cutting will get you banned.
Ticket Validation: There are no turnstiles, but plainclothes inspectors are ruthless. You MUST stamp your ticket in the little machine before boarding. Fine is €60.
Pfand System: Don't crush cans/bottles. They are worth €0.25. Leave them next to bins for collectors if you don't return them yourself.

neighborhoods.name: Kreuzberg
neighborhoods.description: The historic heart of West Berlin's counterculture. Turkish markets, punk bars, street art, and the canal. Gritty, real, and always awake.

neighborhoods.name: Neukölln
neighborhoods.description: The current cool kid. Rough around the edges but packed with trendy vegan cafes, dive bars, and Middle Eastern food. Young, messy, and fun.

neighborhoods.name: Friedrichshain
neighborhoods.description: Home to the legendary Berghain and the RAW-Gelände. Industrial, graffiti-covered, and hedonistic. Where the weekend never ends.

neighborhoods.name: Prenzlauer Berg
neighborhoods.description: A sharp contrast to the grit. Beautifully restored pre-war buildings, organic ice cream, and strollers. It is calm, wealthy, and family-oriented.

neighborhoods.name: Mitte
neighborhoods.description: Berlin's polished center. Museums, landmarks, and upscale shopping. Touristy, but essential for the 'Checklist' sights.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
logistics.summary: Essential friction-removers for a smooth trip.
details: Sunday Lockdown: Almost EVERYTHING is closed (shops, supermarkets). Only restaurants and museums are open. If you need food for Monday morning, buy it Saturday.
Cash is King: Do not assume you can pay with card. Ask 'Kartenzahlung?' before ordering. Carry coins for toilets.
Water: Tap water is safe. Restaurants will fight you on serving it free. Ask for 'Leitungswasser' but be prepared to pay for bottled.
Tipping: Round up. If the bill is €9.20, say 'Ten' (€10) while handing over the money. Do not leave money on the table; tell the waiter the total *before* they charge you.

logistics.title: Club Reality
logistics.summary: Nightlife here is a marathon, not a sprint.
details: The Time Warp: Clubs often open Friday and don't close until Monday morning. A 'weekend' is a single 48-72 hour block. 'After-hours' is just Sunday afternoon.
The Door: Rejections are normal and not personal. Don't argue. Wear comfortable shoes (you will dance for 8 hours).
Safety: Most clubs have awareness teams ('Awareness Team') if you feel unsafe or harassed.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: The U-Bahn (Metro) and S-Bahn (Train) are your lifelines.
details: U-Bahn: Yellow trains, mostly underground. Fast and frequent.
S-Bahn: Red/Yellow trains, mostly above ground. Great for longer distances.
Tickets: Buy a 'Zone AB' ticket. VALIDATE IT by stamping it in the box on the platform. Plainclothes inspectors show no mercy.
Apps: Use 'BVG Fahrinfo' or Google Maps. They are accurate.

logistics.title: Safety Basics
logistics.summary: Berlin is safe, but has rough edges.
details: Görlitzer Park: Known for drug dealers. Generally safe to walk through during the day, but avoid at night.
Pickpockets: Active on crowded tourist lines (U2, U8) and at Alexanderplatz.
Bike Theft: Extremely common. Never leave a bike unlocked, even for a minute.

must_eat.description: Berlin's #1 street food. Invented here. Crispy meat, fresh salad, and garlic sauce in toasted bread. A 'Gemüse Kebap' adds roasted veggies and feta. Don't queue for hours at tourist spots; your local neighborhood Döner is likely just as good.

Beer here is like coffee in Italy: cheap, everywhere, and consumed casually day or night. It is not ceremonial. A 'Wegbier' (road beer) for the walk is culturally normal. Public drinking is legal and common.
Steamed then fried pork sausage cut into slices and drowned in curry ketchup and powder. Served with fries or a bread roll. A cult classic.

The Imbiss is not a restaurant; it is a snack stand where you eat standing up at a tall table. It serves utilitarian, greasy, salty food (fries, sausages, meatballs) designed to keep you moving. Fast, cheap, essential.

When the clubs close (or don't), the Späti is your 24/7 supermarket. They sustain the nightlife economy with frozen pizzas, instant noodles, chips, chocolate bars, and cold beer. It is how you survive 4am.

Berlin is the vegan capital of Europe. You don't need to hunt for it. From dirty punk bars to high-end dining, vegan options are standard, clearly labeled, and delicious. You never have to ask 'is there meat in this?'.
Berlin has a massive Vietnamese community. The Pho, Banh Mi, and Bun Cha here are some of the best in Europe. Look for 'Monsieur Vuong' or holes-in-the-wall in Mitte/Prenzlauer Berg.
Huge, cheap, and delicious. Crispy falafel, hummus, halloumi, and roasted veggies. A staple of Kreuzberg and Neukölln diets.
The fuel of Berlin. A caffeinated, sparkling yerba mate tea. Tastes like cigarette ash the first time, but you'll be addicted by the third bottle.
German bread is world-class. Grab a 'Belegtes Brötchen' (sandwich) or a 'Laugenbrezel' (pretzel) for a cheap breakfast. Breakfast here is savory, simple, and eaten early.
Breaded, fried cutlet (pork or veal). Best enjoyed in a traditional Wirtshaus with potato salad and a cold beer.

items.description: Berlin clubs are not places to be seen; they are places to disappear. They are dark, industrial, and have strict 'no photo' policies. It is about the music and the freedom. The party often lasts from Friday night to Monday morning.
In summer, Berliners leave the city for the lakes (Wannsee, Müggelsee, Schlachtensee). It is pure nature within city limits. Note that FKK (public nudity) is common, non-sexual, and accepted.
An abandoned airport turned into a massive public park. Locals skate on the runways, BBQ, and fly kites. The ultimate symbol of Berlin's freedom.
Skip the expensive bar. Buy a €1.50 beer from a corner store (Späti), sit on the bench outside, and watch the city go by.
A Sunday ritual. Huge flea market followed by public 'Bearpit Karaoke' where thousands cheer on strangers singing.
The symbol of reunification. Best viewed at night when fewer crowds are present. Walk through it to feel the history.
The longest remaining stretch of the Berlin Wall, covered in murals. It's an open-air gallery, free to walk.
A haunting field of 2,711 concrete slabs. Walking into the center is disorienting and powerful. Please remain respectful (no selfies on the blocks).
Abandoned NSA listening station on a hill made of WWII rubble. Covered in graffiti with incredible city views. A bit of a hike.
Located in the former HQ of the East German secret police. A chilling look at surveillance and control.
UNESCO World Heritage site with five world-renowned museums including the Pergamon (check for closures) and Neues Museum.

affiliate_products.title: European Travel Adapter (Type F)
affiliate_products.reason: German plugs are Type F (two round pins). Essential for charging your devices.

affiliate_products.title: Cash Wallet
affiliate_products.reason: Berlin is a cash city. You will need a wallet that can hold coins and bills comfortably.

affiliate_products.title: Portable Charger
affiliate_products.reason: Long nights out and navigating the U-Bahn drain batteries fast. Stay connected.
